title: 106_hr1261
content: The "Long-Term Care Insurance Act of 1999" allows for a deduction on long-term care premiums under section 222 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Long-Term Care Insurance Act of 1999, under section 222 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, allows for a deduction on eligible long-term care premiums paid for coverage under a qualified long-term care insurance contract for the taxpayer, spouse, and dependents. The applicable percentage for the deduction is determined based on a table. The Long-Term Care Insurance Act of 1999, allows for a deduction on eligible long-term care premiums paid for coverage under a qualified long-term care insurance contract. The applicable percentage for the deduction is determined based on a table, with percentages ranging from 20 to 100 for different calendar years. The Long-Term Care Insurance Act of 1999 allows for a deduction on eligible long-term care premiums paid. Special rules apply, such as coordination with medical deduction and denial of deduction to dependents. The Long-Term Care Insurance Act of 1999 allows for a deduction on eligible long-term care premiums paid, with amendments to the tax code to reduce the Earned Income Credit for taxpayers without children. The Long-Term Care Insurance Act of 1999 allows for a deduction on eligible long-term care premiums paid, with amendments to the tax code. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2000. SEC. 3 amends Section 1917(b)(1)(C) of the Social Security Act to allow for the disregard of assets or resources for individuals receiving medical assistance under certain State plans. SEC. 4 focuses on disseminating information about long-term care policies and Medicare coverage. The Congress acknowledges the financial strain on younger Americans due to funding Social Security and Medicare as the baby boom generation retires. Additionally, Medicaid, originally for the poor, is now being used by middle-income elderly for long-term care expenses. The aging population, especially those over 85, will increase significantly in the next decade, leading to a higher demand for long-term care services. With nursing home costs averaging $40,000 to $50,000 per year, these expenses can have a devastating impact on families. Private long-term care insurance can protect families from the catastrophic costs of long-term care services and ease the burden on Medicaid as the baby boom generation ages. The Federal Government has endorsed this concept by establishing tax rules for tax-qualified policies in the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996. The Federal Government has ensured quality long-term care insurance products and sales practices with strict consumer protections in the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996. The Social Security Administration and Health Care Financing Administration will inform the public about the financial risks of long-term care costs and the limitations of Medicare and Medicaid coverage. The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 ensures quality long-term care insurance products with consumer protections. The government encourages employers to offer long-term care insurance to employees and promotes individuals to obtain coverage either through employers or independently.
